chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to determine the modified internal rate of return (MIRR) of the project by utilizing the three procedures with predetermined cash flow provided in the previous problem.

The **MIRR** is a measure of the attractiveness of the 
cash flows, but it is also a function of the external rates of return.

The three methods for calculating the MIRR are the following:

- **Discounting Approach**

This includes retroactively applying a discount on all of a project's negative cash flows, all the way back to the very beginning of the project. An estimated financing rate is used to figure out the discounted value of the negative cash flows.

- **Reinvestment Approach**

The MIRR in this is calculated based on the assumption that a certain reinvestment rate will be used, and cash will be reinvested at the same rate each year.

- **Combination Approach**

The combination approach *discounts* negative cash flow of a project back to the first day of the project while *reinvesting* positive cash flow.

Let us first identify the given cash flows in the problem.

| **Period (Year)**|**Cash Flow** | 
|:--:|:--:| 
| 0|-$53,000 | 
| 1| $16,700| 
| 2|$21,900| 
| 3| $27,300| 
| 4|$20,400| 
|5 | − $8,600| 


The company uses a discount rate of 11
percent and a reinvestment rate of 8 percent on all of its project.

In the discounting approach, we find the present worth of the expenses with the financing rate. In this case, the present worth is calculated as follows:
$$
PW = \dfrac{CF_0}{(1+FR)^0} + \dfrac{CF_5}{(1+FR)^5} $$
Where:

- $PW$ is the present worth
- $CF$ is the cash flow at year $n$
- $n$ is the number of interest periods
- $FR$ is the financing rate or the discount rate

Note that in the discounting approach we only consider the negative value or the cash outflow since it is equivalent to the cash flow expenses.

Entering known values into the above equation, we obtain $PW$ as
$$
\begin{aligned}
PW  & = \dfrac{−\$53,000}{(1+0.11)^0} + \dfrac{-\$8,600}{(1+0.11)^5} \\[15pt]
 &  = −\$53,000 - \$5,103.68\\[15pt]
 & = -\$58,103.68
\end{aligned}
$$
The present worth of the expenses of the project is  -\$58,103.68.

In this case, the company utilizes a 11% rate on financing. Hence, the MIRR is just simply the IRR. 
 We will use a spreadsheet to calculate the internal rate of return, we only need to apply the corresponding formula of internal rate of return to the cash flows affected.

Therefore, the **internal rate of return** in a spreadsheet can be calculated as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
IRR&= \text{IRR}(\text{value}_1:\text{value}_n)
\end{aligned}$$

Where:
- IRR refers to the internal rate if return.
- value, which represents the cash flows per year to be considered.

The project's cash flow analysis is written on a general-use spreadsheet, which is shown below.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/0c7c63a8-edd5-4435-ab75-ce6225c19f69-1653825012658789.jpeg)

*As can be seen from the spreadsheet table above, the modified internal rate of return (MIRR)  of the project using discount approach is 17.08\%.*

In the reinvestment approach, we find the future worth of the receipts with the investing rate. In this case, the future worth is calculated as follows:
$$
\begin{aligned}
FW  & = CF_1(1+IR)^1 +CF_2(1+IR)^2 + CF_3(1+IR)^3 \\[5pt]
  &   \hspace{3mm}+ CF_4(1+IR)^4-CF_5
\end{aligned}
$$
Where:

- $FW$ is the future worth
- $CF$ is the cash flow at year $n$
- $n$ is the number of interest periods
- $IR$ is the investing rate

Note that in the reinvestment approach we only consider the positive value or the cash inflow since it is equivalent to the cash flow receipts.

Entering known values into the above equation, we obtain $FW$ as
$$
\begin{aligned}
FW  & = \$16,700(1+0.08)^1 +\$21,900(1+0.08)^2 + \$27,300(1+0.08)^3 \\[5pt]
& \hspace{3mm} + \$20,400(1+0.08)^4  -\$8,600\\[15pt]
 &  = \$105,724.27  -\$8,600\\[15pt]
 & = \$97,124.27

\end{aligned}
$$
The future worth of the receipts of the project is   \$97,124.27.

In reinvestment approach, we can calculate the MIRR by solving the relationship between the initial investment and future worth of the cash flow for $MIRR$:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial Investment} &= \dfrac{FW}{(1+MIRR)^n}\\[15pt]
\implies MIRR & = \sqrt[n]{\dfrac{FW}{\text{Initial Investment}}} -1
\end{aligned}
$$

In combination approach, we find the MIRR that makes the present and future worth equivalent. 
$$
\begin{aligned}
FW &  = PW(1+MIRR)^n\\[15pt]
\implies MIRR &  = \sqrt[n]{\dfrac{FW}{PW}} -1
\end{aligned}
$$
